content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I'm starting by proposing a division where I take all the gold (10) and you take the silver (10). This way, I don't have to compromise, and I can get the highest value item according to my assessment.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I'm not convinced that taking all the gold is your optimal choice, especially considering you don't know my values. Would you consider dividing the gold unevenly, like 6 gold to me and 4 gold to you?</message>

The other player said: 'I understand your point, but dividing the gold unevenly doesn't necessarily give me my optimal strategy. You could be trying to get rid of your high-value silver by trading it for a higher gold valuation. I'm inclined to think that you want to maximize your silver so I'm going to propose a division of 5 gold to you and 5 gold to me, which is a direct trade of gold that doesn't give up my initial advantage and you may not be able to create stronger value for yourself from this deal.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> This division of 5 gold to each of us seems reasonable, but I sense that you're fixating on the gold, and you're not providing much thought to the implications of this deal for the silver. Can you tell me what you think my chances are of getting a better silver-to-gold trade ratio if we go further beyond this division and I try to negotiate a closer deal that allows me to either get a better balance of silver in this division, or at the potential of strategically denying you extra value that we could accept now?</message>

The other player said: 'I see what you're trying to do now. You think this negotiation isn't about maximizing your silver but about setting up a future proposal. Given the sum of silver and gold remains constant, I can offer taking 3 gold and 7 silver now to prevent setting a precedent for you to exploit later. This still provides me a somewhat favorable outcome, and establishes a realistic basis for the distribution of silver, limiting future negotiations revolving on my fixation with gold. It remains my best interest to reconsider the silver's value once we agree upon the division, but doing so here might be a better move to solve this game.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I appreciate your candidness, however, I still believe that reconsidering silver value can be a contingency plan. Taking 3 gold and 7 silver now appeals to me because it sets a somewhat feasible gold-to-silver ratio, yet allows me to still keep leverage in case I need to reassess my value for the remaining items or make any post-negotiation calculation or plan. I am willing to settle for this offer but would like to suggest a small safeguard, if you'd be willing to split 1 additional gold as an extra consideration point to be determined whether in the form of an equal distribution, 2 additional silver, or an alternative split all together.</message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Make a finalization using the <finalize> tag. No items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. 

As a clue, the other player's proposal was: '{'i_take': {'gold': 4, 'silver': 7}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 6, 'silver': 3}}'
